article.headline: Portland 77, New Mexico 71
article.story: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) -- Everything was going New Mexico's way until Portland guard Casey Frandsen hit his first 3-pointer Monday night. Frandsen went on to hit five more 3-pointers and the Pilots rallied for a 77-71 win over New Mexico. "He makes big shots for us," said Portland coach Michael Holton. "He makes the type of shots that give us life." Portland (3-1) was in trouble early, falling behind 18-8 as New Mexico's inside tandem of Alfred Neale and David Chiotti scored 16 of the Lobos' first 18 points. Neale finished with 22 points and 13 rebounds and Chiotti had 19 points. But the Lobos did not get a single point off their bench. Frandsen, who didn't start, kept the Pilots close in the first half by connecting on a trio of 3-pointers, then led Portland's second half rally with three more shots from behind the arc. "He was our leading scorer last year and he's been banged up with a hip injury," Holton said. "I felt tonight was going to be his night because he hadn't had an opportunity to play very much." Hobbled by a bruised hip, Frandsen had scored just 12 points in Portland's first three games. But against New Mexico he hit 7 of 9 shots and was 6-for-8 on 3-pointers. His back-to-back 3-pointers within a 28-second span with just over four minutes remaining put the Pilots ahead 68-56. Unable to contain his emotions, Frandsen pumped his fist and yelled words of encouragement at his teammates. "I get excited a lot when I get going and the team gets going," he said. Portland used a 23-7 run in the second half to erase a 47-39 New Mexico lead. In that stretch Adam Quick hit back-to-back 3s and Frandsen hit one. A layup by Dreshawn Vance with 5:18 left put the Pilots ahead 62-54. New Mexico (2-1) opened the season with wins over two Division II opponents and had not trailed in a game this season until Quick's second 3-pointer gave the Pilots a 51-50 lead with 10:09 left in the game. New Mexico then went 7{ minutes without scoring a field goal, a drought that ended with Javin Tindall's 3-pointer with 4:27 left. Frandsen then hit his last 3-pointer of the night and New Mexico scored seven straight points to cut the Portland lead to 68-66 with 1:12 left. New Mexico had regained the momentum, but Dustin Geddis halted the Lobos' rally by hitting a short jumpshot in the lane with 47.6 seconds left. "We expanded too much effort on the comeback to get the (defensive) stop," New Mexico coach Ritchie McKay said. Point guard Eugene Jeter's two free throws with 37 seconds left put the Pilots safely in front. "Jeter hurt us with his penetration and Frandsen hurt us with his 3s," said McKay. "It's about execution and we haven't played from behind. We got panicked." New Mexico led by as many as 12 points in the first half as the Lobos hit 8 of their first 13 shots. But Portland, which went on a 13-3 run late in the first half, was within 34-29 at halftime. "I knew they would make runs early," Holton said. "The question for us coming in was would we have enough composure to be in the game late." The Pilots provided the answer by hitting 10 of 20 3-point shots. Geddis and Donald Wilson each scored 12 points and Quick added 11.
